frameDefinitions: These are words describing a basic commercial transaction involving a Buyer and a Seller exchanging Money and Goods, taking the perspective of the Buyer.
An Assailant attacks a Victim, intending to die in the process.
This frame concerns the infliction of punishment in return for a wrong suffered.
An Agent causes the ballistic motion of a projectile and its subsequent impact on a Target.
A Killer or Cause causes the death of the Victim.
The words in this frame describe situations in which an Agent or a Cause injures a Victim.
frameExamples: Abby bought a car from Robin for $5,000.
The terrorist <t>suicide attack</t> on U.S. troops early last week caused more damage than initially reported.
(1) They took <t>revenge</t> for the deaths of two loyalist prisoners.
It looks like he <t>hit</t> the bull's-eye with his first arrow!
Rod saw his father <t>beating</t> his mother.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Buyer</fen> wants the <fen>Goods</fen> and offers <fen>Money</fen> to a <fen>Seller</fen> in exchange for them.
The role <fen>Goods</fen> is anything (including labor or time, for example) which is exchanged for <fen>Money</fen> in a transaction.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
This <fen>Victim</fen> is the being or entity that is injured by the <fen>Assailant</fen>'s suicide attack.
The person (or other self-directed entity) that is attempting physical harm to the <fen>Victim</fen>.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Assailant</fen> attacks the <fen>Victim</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Assailant</fen> makes an assault on the <fen>Victim</fen>.
The <fen>Avenger</fen> exacts revenge from the <fen>Offender</fen> for the <fen>Injury</fen>.
The <fen>Offender</fen> has committed the earlier <fen>Injury</fen> for which the <fen>Avenger</fen> seeks revenge.
The <fen>Avenger</fen> carries out a <fen>Punishment</fen> in order to exact revenge on the <fen>Offender</fen>.

The <fen>Injury</fen> is the injurious action committed by the <fen>Offender</fen> against the <fen>Injured_Party</fen>. This Frame Element need not always be realized, although it is conceptually necessary.

This frame element identifies the constituent that encodes who or what suffered the <fen>Injury</fen> at the hands of the <fen>Offender</fen>. Sometimes, an abstract concept such a person's honour or their blood is presented as the element that has suffered the <fen>Injury</fen>. These also constitute instances of  <fen>Injured_party</fen>
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the revenge occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the revenge occurs.
The entity which is hit by a Projectile directed by the Agent.
The individual that directs the Projectile such that it impacts the Target.
The time at which the <fen>Agent</fen> hits the <fen>Target</fen>.
The location where the event happens.
The person or sentient entity that causes the death of the <fen>Victim</fen>.
The living entity that dies as a result of the killing.
An inanimate entity or process that causes the death of the <fen>Victim</fen>.
The method or action that the <fen>Killer</fen> or <fen>Cause</fen> performs resulting in the death of the <fen>Victim</fen>.
The device used by the <fen>Killer</fen> to bring about the death of the <fen>Victim</fen>.
The point or period of time within which the <fen>Victim</fen> is killed.
The location where the death took place.
<fen>Agent</fen> is the person causing the <fen>Victim</fen>'s injury.

The <fen>Victim</fen> is the being or entity that is injured.  If the <fen>Victim</fen> is included in the phrase indicating <fen>Body_part</fen>, the <fen>Victim</fen> role is tagged on a second role layer (see 3rd example).
The <fen>Body_part</fen> identifies the location on the body where the bodily injury takes place.
The <fen>Cause</fen> marks expressions that indicate some non-intentional, typically non-human, force that inflicts harm on the <fen>Victim</fen>
<fen>Time</fen> identifies the time when the harm-causing event occurs.
<fen>Place</fen> identifies the place where the harm causing event occurs.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Jess</fex> bought a coat.
Only one winner purchased <fex>the paintings</fex>
Her suicide attack <fex>on the guardsmen</fex> was the third such attack in the last month.
<fex>The group's</fex> suicide attacks continue to affect troop morale.
<fex>Last Tuesday's</fex> suicide attack killed seven and wounded 20.
Last week's suicide bombing <fex>outside the city</fex> was the first in weeks.
<fex>We</fex> want to avenge her.
Jo had the affair as a kind of revenge <fex>against Pat</fex>.
The team took revenge <fex>with a resounding victory</fex>.
The team sought revenge <fex>for their 4-1 defeat last month</fex>.
Sam's brothers avenged <fex>him</fex>.
<fex>The rockslide</fex> killed nearly half of the climbers.
The flood exterminated the rats <fex>by cutting off access to food</fex>.
It's difficult to suicide <fex>with only a pocketknife</fex>.
There is no evidence that the royal family was killed <fex>during the destruction</fex> at this site.
Apparently there were two murders <fex>in Atherton</fex> in one week.
<fex>Jolosa, who</fex> broke a rival player 's jaw, was told to model his play on the England striker.
Someone bashed <fex>him</fex> on the back of the head with a heavy smooth object.
Someone bashed him <fex>on the back of the head</fex> with a heavy smooth object.
<fex>A falling rock</fex> crushed my ankle.
Riot police in Nairobi clubbed four women unconscious <fex>on March 3</fex>.
Boys  are punched <fex>at school</fex> for payback

sourceCandidateSpans.text: Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons
